thread.title: Portland coastguard helicopter in search for youths reported trapped on Torquay rocks | Devon Live
thread.title_full: Portland coastguard helicopter in search for youths reported trapped on Torquay rocks | Devon Live

title: Portland coastguard helicopter in search for youths reported trapped on Torquay rocks | Devon Live
text:
Comments (0) 
The Coastguard rescue helicopter joined ground teams and a Torbay lifeboat crew in a search for youths reported trapped under cliffs in Torquay on Sunday. A passer-by dialled 999 when he saw from the other end of Torre Abbey sands what he thought were two youths caught by the tide on the rocks at Corbyn Head. 
The alarm was raised at 4.45pm and the Coastguard helicopter from Portland was brought in as well as a Torbay Coastguard team of ten and the inshore Torbay lifeboat. 
John Bunce, sector officer for Torbay Coastguard, said they had reports that one of the youths had gone into the water apparently fully clothed. 
"When we arrived on the scene there were no obvious signs of the youths. The inshore lifeboat fully checked the walkway and caves under the cliff and scanned the water in the area in case there were any casualties, as did the helicopter. 
"The coastguard put a cliff man on the edge to look over down to the area where the caller said he had seen the youths. Nobody was located, we can only assume the youths had made their way back. There were quite a few youths on the beach and it may have been connected with that." 
A Coastguard helicopter was also in Torquay earlier in the afternoon for crew training. 
READ MORE: 
Torquay's iconic Riviera Wheel - back for five years? 
Torquay's much loved Riviera Wheel could be back in town for a further five years. But planners are being asked for a new site to be found. Happily for its fans the proposed new site is only just over 100 metres further away in the seafront Princess Gardens. 
Excitement as South Devon's humpback whale spotted off Brixham 
Walkers enjoying Brixham's nature reserve at Berry Head got a big surprise on Sunday morning when they spotted a humpback whale offshore. The whale which has been ranging up and down the shore off Slapton and Torcross for the past three weeks to the delight of nature lovers had obviously gone off for a bit of a stroll further along the South Devon coast.Alex Foley who runs the Guardhouse Cafe at Berry Head national nature reserve said the whale had been spotted next to a fishing boat at about 9.30am. 
Motion made to protect Devon's nature after Brexit 
A motion calling to protect Devon's nature from the risks of leaving the European Union has been endorsed by Devon County Council's cabinet.It has been recommended to full council next month that councillors support a coalition of green charities and a government environmental committee, asking the government to apply at least the same level of protection in UK law as exists under EU law.
